items.title: python feather-format 0.4.0 is incompatible with pyarrow 0.17.0: ImportError FeatherError FeatherReader FeatherWriter
items.body:
Installed `feather-format` and `pyarrow` in python 3.8.2 today, ran into this problem resulting in an `ImportError`.

The `feather` script `api.py` tries to import:

```python
from pyarrow.feather import (read_feather as read_dataframe,  # noqa
                             write_feather as write_dataframe,
                             FeatherError,
                             FeatherReader,
                             FeatherWriter)
```
But in pyarrow 0.17.0, `FeatherError` and `FeatherReader` have moved to `pyarrow.lib`. I don't know where `FeatherWriter` went, I couldn't find it.

So, I uninstalled `pyarrow` and `python -m pip install pyarrow==0.16.0` instead, fixed the problem.

Just a heads up that people will start running into this problem.

items.title: [Feature request] allow datetime index
items.body:
I have hourly data for 3 years using a datetime as the index. Pandas allows me load/save with the following code (only one month with 2 variables shown):
`
# Write data to .csv
jan90.to_csv('PEC fine course 1 grid 199001.csv', index=True)
# Load data from .csv
jan90 = pd.read_csv('PEC fine course 1 grid 199001.csv', index_col=0, parse_dates=True)
`
Using .csv works, but is slow when I get to the full dataset of 26k+ rows and 21.6k+ columns (and more columns may be coming if I have to add lags to my data). So, a more efficient load/save routine is very desirable. I was excited when I found feather, but the lost index is a no-go for my use.

Thanks for your consideration.

items.title: In R, Feather cannot read dataframe back if missing or having empty column header
items.body:
In R, when calling `read_feather` function to load the cache, it could fail with error to ask to name columns, if the original dataframe is missing one, which is quite common for datasets (e.g. no index/rownames header). 

The error seems to do with the `tibble` package in the implementation.

If the column name is required, `write_feather` should ask for it if missing in the first place; or the implementation should allow missing columns.

Code example to show the bug is as below:
```r
> library(feather) 
> n = c(2, 3, 5) 
> s = c("aa", "bb", "cc") 
> b = c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE) 
> df = data.frame(n, s, b)
> df
  n  s     b
1 2 aa  TRUE
2 3 bb FALSE
3 5 cc  TRUE
> colnames(df)[1] <- ""
> df
     s     b
1 2 aa  TRUE
2 3 bb FALSE
3 5 cc  TRUE
> write_feather(df, '~/cache/test.feather')
> df2 <- read_feather('~/cache/test.feather')
Error: Column 1 must be named.
Use .name_repair to specify repair.
Run `rlang::last_error()` to see where the error occurred.
>
> rlang::last_error()
<error/rlang_error>
Column 1 must be named.
Use .name_repair to specify repair.
Backtrace:
  1. feather::read_feather("~/cache/test.feather")
  3. tibble:::as_tibble.default(data)
  6. feather:::as.data.frame.feather(value, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
  9. tibble:::as_tibble.data.frame(x[])
 10. tibble:::as_tibble.list(unclass(x), ..., .rows = .rows, .name_repair = .name_repair)
 11. tibble:::lst_to_tibble(x, .rows, .name_repair, col_lengths(x))
 12. tibble:::set_repaired_names(x, .name_repair)
 17. tibble:::repaired_names(names(x), .name_repair = .name_repair)
 18. tibble:::check_unique(new_name)
Run `rlang::last_trace()` to see the full context.
```

items.title: Should feather::read_feather respect options(stringsAsFactors = FALSE)?
items.body:
Greetings!

Is there any reason why the R implementation of `read_feather()` ignores the state of the `stringsAsFactors` option?

For consistency, it seems like it would be useful to have it behave in a similar manner to `read.delim()`, `read_tsv()`, etc...

Ex:

```r
library(feather)
library(tidyverse)
options(stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

write_tsv(head(iris), 'test.tsv')
write_feather(head(iris), 'test.feather')

head(read.delim('test.tsv', sep='\t')$Species)
# [1] "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa"

head(read_tsv('test.tsv', col_types = cols())$Species)
# [1] "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa"

head(read_feather('test.feather')$Species)
# [1] setosa setosa setosa setosa setosa setosa
# Levels: setosa versicolor virginica
```

Incidentally, I checked `read_parquet()` and it too ignores `stringAsFactors`.

**Versions**:

- R 3.6.2
- feather 0.3.5

items.title: Is it possible to save feather file in compressed zip format?
items.body:
I need to save feather data in a more compact format. After making several tests I found that after using the "zip" function the size of the "feather" data file reduce up to 90%. 

So, there is a simple question - does anyway to save data as a "feather" file with let say argument like "compressed = zip" to save disk space. 

library(feather)
library(zip)

# Write data in feather format
write_feather(df, "data.feather)

# Write data in zip feather format
zip("data.feather.zip", "data.feather")

# How to have commands like these ones without using disk space for temp file ?
write_feather(df, "data.feather.zip", format = "zip")
df <- read_feather("data.feather.zip", format = "zip")


Thanks!

items.title: "cannot serialize duplicate column names"
Support for set/list columns in python
items.body:
Hi,

Using python 3.6.7, pandas 0.24.2, pyarrow  0.14.1 on WSL in Windows 10...

```python
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'a': [1,2,3], 'b': [set([1,2]), set([2,3]), set([3,4,5])]})

df.to_feather('test.ft')
```

I get:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/gioras/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/core/frame.py", line 2131, in to_feather
    to_feather(self, fname)
  File "/home/gioras/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/io/feather_format.py", line 83, in to_feather
    feather.write_feather(df, path)
  File "/home/gioras/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/feather.py", line 182, in write_feather
    writer.write(df)
  File "/home/gioras/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/feather.py", line 93, in write
    table = Table.from_pandas(df, preserve_index=False)
  File "pyarrow/table.pxi", line 1174, in pyarrow.lib.Table.from_pandas
  File "/home/gioras/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/pandas_compat.py", line 496, in dataframe_to_arrays
    for c, f in zip(columns_to_convert, convert_fields)]
  File "/home/gioras/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/pandas_compat.py", line 496, in <listcomp>
    for c, f in zip(columns_to_convert, convert_fields)]
  File "/home/gioras/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/pandas_compat.py", line 487, in convert_column
    raise e
  File "/home/gioras/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/pandas_compat.py", line 481, in convert_column
    result = pa.array(col, type=type_, from_pandas=True, safe=safe)
  File "pyarrow/array.pxi", line 191, in pyarrow.lib.array

pyarrow.lib.ArrowInvalid: ('Could not convert {1, 2} with type set: did not recognize Python value type when inferring an Arrow data type', 'Conversion failed for column b with type object')
```

And obviously `df.drop('b', axis=1).to_feather('test.ft')` works.

items.title: Feather doesn't preserve datetime.date type when reading a dataframe
items.body:
My goal is to keep just the date portion of the datetime object in the 'date' column. Here's an example

```python
import pandas as pd
import feather

data = {'date': ['2014-05-01 18:47:05.069722', '2014-05-01 18:47:05.119994', 
                 '2014-05-02 18:47:05.178768', '2014-05-02 18:47:05.230071', 
                 '2014-05-02 18:47:05.230071', '2014-05-02 18:47:05.280592']}
df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns = ['date'])

df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date']).dt.date
print(type(df['date'].iloc[1]))
>>> datetime.date
```
However, when I feather save this data frame and, subsequently, load it, the 'date' column turns into a Panda's timestamp type.

```python
df.to_feather('df')
df = feather.read_dataframe('df')
```

items.title: crazy timestamp bug in feather?
items.body:
Hello the dream team,

Thanks for this wonderful package. I was playing with feather and some timestamps and I noticed some dangerous behavior. Maybe it is a bug. 

Consider this

```
import pandas as pd
import feather
import numpy as np


df = pd.DataFrame({'string_time_utc' : [pd.to_datetime('2018-02-01 14:00:00.531'), 
                                  pd.to_datetime('2018-02-01 14:01:00.456'),
                                  pd.to_datetime('2018-03-05 14:01:02.200')]})

df['timestamp_est'] = pd.to_datetime(df.string_time_utc).dt.tz_localize('UTC').dt.tz_convert('US/Eastern').dt.tz_localize(None)

df
Out[17]: 
          string_time_utc           timestamp_est
0 2018-02-01 14:00:00.531 2018-02-01 09:00:00.531
1 2018-02-01 14:01:00.456 2018-02-01 09:01:00.456
2 2018-03-05 14:01:02.200 2018-03-05 09:01:02.200
```
Here I create the corresponding `EST` timestamp of my original timestamps (in `UTC` time).

Now saving the dataframe to `csv` or to `feather` will generate two completely different results.

```
df.to_csv('P://testing.csv')
df.to_feather('P://testing.feather')
```
Switching to R. 

Using the good old `csv` gives me something a bit annoying, but expected. R thinks my timezone is `UTC` by default, and wrongly attached this timezone to `timestamp_est`. No big deal, I can always use `with_tz` or even better: import as character and process as timestamp while in R.

```
> dataframe <- read_csv('P://testing.csv')
Parsed with column specification:
cols(
  X1 = col_integer(),
  string_time_utc = col_datetime(format = ""),
  timestamp_est = col_datetime(format = "")
)
Warning message:
Missing column names filled in: 'X1' [1] 
> 
> dataframe %>% mutate(mytimezone = tz(timestamp_est))
# A tibble: 3 x 4
     X1 string_time_utc         timestamp_est          
  <int> <dttm>                  <dttm>                 
1     0 2018-02-01 14:00:00.530 2018-02-01 09:00:00.530
2     1 2018-02-01 14:01:00.456 2018-02-01 09:01:00.456
3     2 2018-03-05 14:01:02.200 2018-03-05 09:01:02.200
  mytimezone
  <chr>     
1 UTC       
2 UTC       
3 UTC 
```
Now look at what happens with `feather`:

```
> dataframe <- read_feather('P://testing.feather')
> 
> dataframe %>% mutate(mytimezone = tz(timestamp_est))
# A tibble: 3 x 3
  string_time_utc         timestamp_est           mytimezone
  <dttm>                  <dttm>                  <chr>     
1 2018-02-01 09:00:00.531 2018-02-01 04:00:00.531 ""        
2 2018-02-01 09:01:00.456 2018-02-01 04:01:00.456 ""        
3 2018-03-05 09:01:02.200 2018-03-05 04:01:02.200 ""     
```
My timestamps have been converted!!! pure insanity. 
Am I missing something here?

Thanks!!

items.title: pyarrow.lib.ArrowTypeError:  "Expected a string or bytes object, got a 'int' object"
items.body:
could in-place type coercion or promotion be applied with a warning to prevent this?

```py
import pandas as pd

testdf = pd.DataFrame({'testcol':['item1', 'item2', 3, 'item4']})

testdf.to_feather('testdf.feather')

```

end of Traceback
```py
 File "pyarrow/array.pxi", line 182, in pyarrow.lib.array
 File "pyarrow/array.pxi", line 82, in pyarrow.lib._ndarray_to_array
 File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 91, in pyarrow.lib.check_status
pyarrow.lib.ArrowTypeError: ("Expected a string or bytes object, got a 'int' object", 'Conversion failed for column testcol with type object')

```


Simple work-around:

```py
import pandas as pd

testdf = pd.DataFrame({'testcol':['item1', 'item2', 3, 'item4']})
testdf['testcol'] = testdf['testcol'].astype(str)

testdf.to_feather('testdf.feather')
```

Hey.
So openml.org is looking (aka I'm trying to convince them) to move away from ARFF as the primary storage format.
I'm trying to understand the scope of feather better to see if it's a candidate.
Sorry if this has been answered elsewhere, I'm not trying to revive #188.

Using feature-hashing can go even more extreme where there might be tens of millions of columns, some of them potentially completely empty.

Thanks!

df <- tibble(x = c(Sys.time(), NA, NaN))
print(df)
 A tibble: 3 x 1

So far nothing special. But if instead you write and read this table in feather format, you will get the following:
feather::write_feather(df, "df.feather")
df2 <- feather::read_feather("df.feather")
print(df2)
 A tibble: 3 x 1
  x                  
  \<dttm\>             
1 2018-03-07 10:39:29
2 NA                 
3 -290308-12-21 19:59:06

In words: NaN's are saved as the datetime value -290308-12-21 19:59:06 but "ordinary" NA's are kept as NAs.

Best, Paul

items.title: Date class from R -> Python -> R is not retained
items.body:
When writing a `tibble` with a `Date` column from `R -> feather -> Pandas -> feather -> R`, the `Date` class is lost and becomes `POSIXct`. 

I think this is happening when the python version of `feather` reads the file and converts it to a pandas DataFrame. It brings in the date column as `datetime64[ns]` which is then resaved as `datetime`, not `date`. But I am not sure if this is actually where the problem lies.

Using `reticulate` in R, here is a full reproducible example.

``` r
library(reticulate)
library(feather)
library(tibble)

PY_FEATHER <- import("feather")

tf <- tempfile(fileext = "feather")
tf2 <- tempfile(fileext = "feather")

ex <- tibble(date_col = as.Date("2018-01-01"))
ex
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>   date_col  
#>   <date>    
#> 1 2018-01-01

feather::write_feather(ex, tf)

# No problem here
feather::read_feather(tf)
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>   date_col  
#>   <date>    
#> 1 2018-01-01

# Metadata is "date". This is correct.
feather::feather_metadata(tf)
#> <Feather file>
#> [1 x 1] @ /var/folders/ln/vjgktwwx50jcvm7jq7jlnsbr0000gn/T//Rtmp3en49k/file13e6755c571eefeather
#> * 'date_col': date

# Now read into pandas
ex_pd <- PY_FEATHER$read_dataframe(tf)

ex_pd
#>     date_col
#> 0 2018-01-01

# And write it back using feather
PY_FEATHER$write_dataframe(ex_pd, tf2)

# Now read it back into R - Lost date, now reading as datetime
feather::read_feather(tf2)
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>   date_col           
#>   <dttm>             
#> 1 2017-12-31 19:00:00

# The metadata is written incorrectly as datetime
feather::feather_metadata(tf2)
#> <Feather file>
#> [1 x 1] @ /var/folders/ln/vjgktwwx50jcvm7jq7jlnsbr0000gn/T//Rtmp3en49k/file13e6715baec40feather
#> * 'date_col': datetime
```

Created on 2018-02-15 by the [reprex package](http://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.1.1.9000).

items.title: [QUESTION] Feather 0.4.0 could be slower than Feather 0.3.1?
items.body:
Hi,
Having the intention to move from Feather 0.3.1 to Feather 0.4.0, I did a quick test that consisted of reading a .csv compressed that contains around 33 millions of records where each record has 4 columns:
  ....
07300003030539,42198997,-1,2016-10-03T13:14:22.326Z
41130003053286,42224636,-1,2016-09-20T19:31:51.196Z
....
Once the file was read in a dataframe, a feather file was generated and read again as a feather file. The entire test is something like this:

df = pd.read_table(fn,sep=',',header=0)

%time feather.write_dataframe(df,'/var/tmp/df1.fth')
With feather 0.3.1
CPU times: user 2.32 s, sys: 3.16 s, total: 5.48 s
Wall time: 8.3 s

With feather 0.4.0
CPU times: user 8.81 s, sys: 3.06 s, total: 11.9 s
Wall time: 14.7 s


%time df = feather.read_dataframe('/var/tmp/df1.fth')
With feather 0.3.1
CPU times: user 3.22 s, sys: 2.13 s, total: 5.35 s
Wall time: 5.35 s

With feather 0.4.0
CPU times: user 4.43 s, sys: 3.4 s, total: 7.83 s
Wall time: 7.83 s

For installing feather 0.4.0, I needed to install pyarrow 0.8.0.

I know that this is just one example but I was expecting  the other way around, i.e., feather 0.4.0 + pyarrow 0.8.0 exceeds feather 0.3.1.

Is there an easy explanation for this result? Please, could you suggest another test where I can check that the upgrade from 0.3.1 to 0.4.0 is worth in terms of speed?

Thanks very much in advance.

items.title: Feature request: Read and write dataset description in both R and Python
items.body:
The R-help for `feather_metadata` states: "Returns the dimensions, field names, and types; and optional dataset description.". @hrbrmstr Kindly posted a [PR](https://github.com/wesm/feather/pull/326) to make this feature work and read and write a dataset description to a feather file from R. The dataset description could contain variable definitions, data source, etc., perhaps in markdown format.

It would be great if it were possible to read (and write) such a dataset description in python / pandas using feather.read_dataframe and feather.write_dataframe as well. I searched the documentation but couldn't find any information about this. It was hoping something like the following might work:

import feather
import pandas as pd
dat = pd.DataFrame({'a': [1, 2, 3], 'b': [4, 5, 6]})
dat._metadata = "# Test dataset\n\nThis dataset contains information on ..."
feather.write_dataframe(dat, "pydf.feather")

Or else perhaps:

feather.write_dataframe(dat, "pydf.feather", "# Test dataset\n\nThis dataset contains information on ...")

See also this [post on SO](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47917549/read-and-write-a-dataset-description-as-a-pandas-dataframe-attribute)

items.title: Cannot convert pyarrow.lib.ChunkedArray to pyarrow.lib.Array
items.body:
When trying to use pandas df.to_feather() method, it seems to work well with smaller datasets, however with a larger dataset I'm trying to use it with (~210GB) I get various errors.

Error 1.) Columns that contain all np.nan values throw exception ValueError: cannot serialize column named col_name with dtype floating

I looked around about this error and found the issue wesm/feather#295 which seemed to have closed the same issue with the update to feather 0.4, however I am using 0.4 right now and the issue appears to still be there only when using large datasets.
To temporarily get around this, I check each column and drop those that are all np.nan before attempting to feather. Then I run into issue 2:

Error 2.) Cannot feather large datasets. Throwing exception: TypeError: Cannot convert pyarrow.lib.ChunkedArray to pyarrow.lib.Array. This is happening in File "pyarrow/feather.pxi", line 62, in pyarrow.lib.FeatherWriter.write_array

items.title: read_feather method does not restore a dataframe's table-level user-defined properties (attributes or tags or metadata)
items.body:
I create a property named _someid_ (it is NOT a column) in a pandas dataframe named _df_ and assign it a value:
`df.someid = 24`
I make sure the property is there:
`print(df.someid)  #prints 24`
I save the dataframe to a feather file:
`df.to_feather("C:/pandas/DataLoss.feather")`
I read the feather file back into a dataframe:
`df = pd.read_feather("C:/pandas/DataLoss.feather")`
I try to retrieve the property from the dataframe:
`print(df.someid)  `
And I do not get its value (24) back.  Instead I get this error message:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-99-42d4540986ab> in <module>()
----> 1 print(df.someid)

~\Anaconda3\envs\env_feather\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py in __getattr__(self, name)
   3079             if name in self._info_axis:
   3080                 return self[name]
-> 3081             return object.__getattribute__(self, name)
   3082 
   3083     def __setattr__(self, name, value):

AttributeError: 'DataFrame' object has no attribute 'someid'
```

1.  This may well be by design, although afaik undocumented, but it seems to me that an error should be generated whenever user data is lost--if the feather format is intended to be the native storage format for a pandas dataframe.  (However, the inability to store indexes is documented; fwiw, I wish that limitation weren't present either.)
2.  Or it may be there is a newer, better way of specifying user properties (tags / metadata) that I don't know about, in which case perhaps the old method should give a warning and be deprecated.
3.  Note that I could store the property as a column (as a repeating constant), but that uses up significant space as the number of rows increases (as the value repeats on every row)--even if stored as a categorical.  That wouldn't be an issue if there were compression, but there appears not to be compression.  I could use parquet format instead, and perhaps in the latest release that would be recommended over feather format.  (I haven't seen a good comparison of the pros and cons of each.)

Thanks for any assistance or comments.  (--Apologies in advance if I missed something in the docs or online; I didn't see anything relevant after a reasonable search, except the unapproved use of the undocumented __metadata_.)  

I realize there are thorny, perhaps unresolvable, problems with dataframe table-level metadata propagation (e.g. how to handle vertical dataframe concatenations), but I think what happens (by design) should be documented.  As it is, I don't know what is supposed to be happening by design here.

items.title: Feather current state / future?
items.body:
Wes, feel free to point me somewhere else if this is the wrong forum for this. I'm intrigued with Feather and Arrow and am curious as to where things stand right now. Particularly in light of these comments:

> As time has passed, as one might expect, quite a bit of code overlap has developed between Feather's C++ and Python components and Apache Arrow's respective C++ and Python libraries. To address this, I'm planning to merge the Feather implementation into the Arrow codebase, which will enable me to provide better performance and new features to Feather users. ([Source](http://wesmckinney.com/blog/outlook-for-2017/).)

> Feather is not designed for long-term data storage. At this time, we do not guarantee that the file format will be stable across versions. Instead, use Feather for quickly exchanging data between Python and R code, or for short-term storage of data frames as part of some analysis. ([Source](https://blog.cloudera.com/blog/2016/03/feather-a-fast-on-disk-format-for-data-frames-for-r-and-python-powered-by-apache-arrow/).)

I'm transitioning to Python / Pandas (from SAS and Stata) and really like the performance and interoperability aspects of Arrow and Feather. Is it still too early for me to rely on either for long-term storage? Also, it sounds like Feather is being deprecated. If I'm just getting started with both, should I be focused on Arrow?

Appreciate your thoughts as well as everything you've put into developing this!

items.title: Tibble with Date column is not identical to itself after writing and reading with feather
items.body:
Let's consider the tibble

```r
x <- tibble::tibble(start_date = lubridate::ymd(NA, NA, "2016-01-01", "2018-04-01", NA))
```
Obviously it is identical to itself

```r
testthat::expect_identical(x, x)
```

But if i write the file to disk and then I read it then I get an error

```r
library(feather)
write_feather(x, "x.feather")
x_feather <- read_feather("x.feather")
system("rm x.feather")
testthat::expect_identical(x, x_feather)

# Error: `x` not identical to `x_feather`.
# Rows in x but not y: 1. Rows in y but not x: 1. 

```

items.title: Status of JS reader for feather files
items.body:
JupyterLab will soon have the ability to render very large tables (millions of rows in memory, trillions for virtual datasets). We are starting to look at building native feature support into JupyterLab so a user can simply click on a feather file and view it interactively. The main barrier for us is having a solid JS library for parsing the files into consumable JSON data.

I see there is some sort of JS bindings in this repo and am wondering about their maturity, stability, etc. Are folks open to some refactoring into an installable npm package?

Here is the issue on JupyterLab tracking these things:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/2422

The table viewer we will be using is in phosphor.js here:

https://github.com/phosphorjs/phosphor/pull/283

items.title: Are write_feather/read_feather atomic operation?
items.body:
I use feather to cache long-running computation in R as it's extremely fast for writing/reading data.frames. When doing computation in parallel, is it necessary to add file lock before each write/read to avoid such situations as one process is writing a cached data.frame and another process could find the file and read in the uncompleted cache? In another words, are write_feather/read_feather atomic?

I have done some test. It seems working well without lock. And I have tried to dive into the underlying C++ code, but have found nothing as I have little knowledge on C++. So, could anyone give  an clear answer on this?

Thanks in advance.

items.title: Creating feather files from data stream with small memory footprint
items.body:
Hello,

This is very similary to issue #272, but for writing feather files.

I am planning to use arrow's C++ API (installed in `arrow/ipc/api.h`) to create **feather** files so I can rapidly read them in R to ingest data in my tidyverse code. So, as of now, the only way to do it is to keep all columns in memory (using `arrow::DoubleBuilder->Append` for each column as objects in the data stream arrive) and at the end, when the stream finishes, call `feather_table->Append` with the name of each column and the corresponding in-memory array of values. The problem is that my input is a stream, and I want to avoid keep it all in memory. So, in a hypothetical ideal scenario, I'd create one table row at a time (eventually buffering multiple rows for performance reasons) and do a "row bind" operation in feather's TableWriter periodically. Such scenario, as far as I known, is impossible with the current arrow's feather C++ API since it let me manage only finished columns.

An `R` alternative would be to call `read_csv` (from the `readr` package) once the stream is finished, and them `write_feather` to get the appropriate feather files; but I want to avoid CSV files. Despite being slow on scale (> 100M lines with ~20 columns each), the costly parsing procedure creates a lot of temporary objects in memory.

What would be the best way, if possible, to do this with feather files? Thanks.

items.title: Timestamp, Time, Date, and Category types values aren't written to disk
items.body:
In my efforts to create a [.NET implementation of a Feather reader/writer](https://github.com/kevin-montrose/FeatherDotNet), I discovered that some column type values are never written to disk.

In particular

 - [CATEGORY](https://github.com/wesm/feather/blob/master/cpp/src/feather/metadata.fbs#L23) is serialized as an INT32
 - [DATE](https://github.com/wesm/feather/blob/master/cpp/src/feather/metadata.fbs#L26) also as an INT32
 - [TIMESTAMP](https://github.com/wesm/feather/blob/master/cpp/src/feather/metadata.fbs#L25) as an INT64
 - [TIME](https://github.com/wesm/feather/blob/master/cpp/src/feather/metadata.fbs#L27)  also as an INT64

In each case the "actual" type can be distinguished based on the column's associated metadata.

Is this behavior intended?  If so, it would probably make sense to remove CATEGORY, DATE, TIMESTAMP, and TIME from the [list of Types](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/arrow/ipc/feather.fbs#L27) and document their expected underlying types (or are they allowed to vary?).

items.title: uint64 in python lib can't actually deal with uint values bigger than uint32.max
items.body:
The python library can write `uint64` (also called `u8` in the python code) values, but it actually fails with values whose internal representation is bigger than will fit in 4 bytes.

Here's my reproduction from a REPL:

```python
# import the things
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import feather as f
>>> import pandas as pd

# grab type info for uint32 and uint64
>>> uint32 = np.iinfo('uint32')
>>> uint64 = np.iinfo('uint64')

# write out a uint32 data frame - works okay
>>> f.write_dataframe(pd.DataFrame({'a':[uint32.min, 0, uint32.max]}), '/tmp/out32.feather')

# write out a uint64 data frame - we have an issue based on pd.lib.infer_dtype
>>> f.write_dataframe(pd.DataFrame({'a':[uint64.min, 0, uint64.max]}), '/tmp/out64.feather')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "feather/api.py", line 56, in write_dataframe
    raise ValueError(msg)
ValueError: cannot serialize column 0 named a with dtype integer
```

https://github.com/wesm/feather/blob/master/python/feather/api.py#L42-L56

items.title: error writing python bytes type
items.body:
I get an error when trying to write a df with bytes in the column (strings cause no issue):
```
d = DataFrame([b'abc'], columns=['A'])
feather.write_dataframe(d, '/tmp/x.fth')
=> ValueError: cannot serialize column 0 named A with dtype bytes
```

Not sure if it's a bug or intentional design. On the python [readme](https://github.com/wesm/feather/blob/master/python/README.md), it says a limitation of the project is

> Object-type columns with non-homogeneous data

but that doesn't seem to apply here.

items.title: Ruby bindings for Feather?
items.body:
Not an issue rather a question :)
Are there any plans on implementing feather bindings for Ruby?

items.title: Single-writer Multiple-readers
items.body: HDF5 has the ability to have a single-writer and multiple-readers ("swmr"), which is very useful for scenarios where you have one process receiving a data stream that you want to get on disk as fast as possible but also have several other processes monitoring the incoming data (ex. one visualizing the raw feed, one doing realtime signal detection stuff, etc). It would be great if feather could support this too.

items.title: [Python] 0.3.1 regression or confusing error message?
items.body:
The following snippet:

```
import pandas as pd
import feather

feather.write_dataframe(pd.DataFrame({'c': [True]}, dtype='object'), "xxx.feather")
```

Will yield the following error in 0.3.1 but no error 0.3.0:

```
cannot serialize column 0 named c with dtype boolean
```

I guess I can see how the change in 0.3.1 added validation against such imprecise dtypes. But it still seems like it should either give a better message (that dtype is actually object) or still allow the more general type here.

items.title: Read multiple feathers into a single tibble
items.body:
There are many applications where people break up data into several medium-sized objects. It would be great to be able to read multiple feathers into a single tibble object without an intermediate step.

In the below, the memory used is double what should be necessary:
```
library(feather)
library(tidyverse)
iris_big <- bind_rows(lapply(1:10000, function(x) iris)) %>% 
  as_tibble()
pryr::object_size(iris_big)
write_feather(iris_big, "tmp1.feather")
write_feather(iris_big, "tmp2.feather")
pryr::mem_change({
  featherdf1 <- read_feather("tmp1.feather")
  featherdf2 <- read_feather("tmp2.feather")
  final_df <- bind_rows(featherdf1, featherdf2)
})
````
This doesn't work, but might be how this could go:
```
pryr::mem_change({
  feather1 <- feather("tmp1.feather")
  feather2 <- feather("tmp2.feather")
  final_df <- bind_rows(feather1, feather2) %>% collect()
})
file.remove("tmp1.feather", "tmp2.feather")
```

items.title: Row by row streaming
items.body:
My use case involves reading data frames row by row from C++. From what I have dug so far such functionality would be difficult to build upon feather. There is no support for streaming in flattbuffers and arrow layout is column based which presumably(?) rules out efficient row by row access.  

Any thoughts?

items.title: Documentation: basic C++ howto and data structures description
items.body:
Is there any user level documentation out there on the underlying data structure and supported operations? Or the C++ codebase is the only "doc" at the moment?  Particularly, what data types are supported and how they are stored, and what kind of random access read/write operations are supported (extracting columns, appending columns, extract or write an indexed range of columns etc).  

Would be nice have a basic "hello world" example of how to operate on metadata and read and write all supported data types from C++.  And maybe a high level meta discussion of what problems the format solves and how it concretely relates to "arrow" project would be very much appreciated. 

Thank you.

items.title: Slightly confusing error messages with unsupported data?
items.body:
Say you run

```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import feather

df = pd.DataFrame({'nope': np.array([2.0, 3.5], dtype=np.float16)})
feather.write_dataframe(df, 'test.feather')
```

this raises `FeatherError: Invalid: unsupported type 23` ( The corresponding error for the same offense in the `julia` wrapper is `LoadError: KeyError: key Float16 not found`)


if you run 

```python
df = pd.DataFrame({'nope': np.array([np.nan, np.nan], dtype=np.object)})
feather.write_dataframe(df, 'test.feather')
```

you get `ValueError: cannot serialize column 0 named nope with dtype floating`. (in `julia`: `LoadError: argument is an abstract type; size is indeterminate`)

In the first case, I would be at fault for not realising that the [list of supported column types](https://github.com/wesm/feather) does not include `Float16`. The second case is very contrived, but happened to pop up when I foolishly tried to convert a messy CSV to feather without cleaning it first, and at first glance that column looked like a float. 

My point was just if you get error messages like these on a large dataframes, it can be hard to pinpoint the offending column and what the problem is. In the python wrapper [check_status](https://github.com/wesm/feather/blob/master/python/feather/ext.pyx#L52) could maybe print the offending column name? (Perhaps the different wrappers could harmonize the error messages?)  Sorry if this is just me being slow (please close this issue if so).
